10.61.text:
- As part of the new      
      segment to the show

14.65.text:
we will be talking to        
   local authors and writers

17.15.text:
who have had an            
     impact on this region,

19.75.text:
or whom this region        
     has had an impact on.

23.02.text:
Today we have a man who's    
   a writer in residence

25.99.text:
at Augustana College, and    
   a man of short stories.

29.53.text: His latest book was a finalist

31.40.text: for the High Plains Book Award,

33.50.text:
and shares the many          
   stories of the many faces

38.54.text:
Ladies and gentlemen,      
     I'm proud to say

40.51.text:
that today's guest is Sioux    
 Falls resident, Patrick Hicks.

45.44.text:
- Oh, it's a real pleasure   
   to be on the show.

49.08.text:
Now Patrick, tell me a        
  little bit about your book,

53.59.text:
Well, it represents        
     over 10 years of work.

56.19.text:
Really, it was my           
    learning the trade craft

58.39.text:
of how to write shorter     
    narrative fiction.

61.69.text:
Because I figured if      
      I could figure out

63.00.text:
how to really nail down     
    how to do a short story,

66.07.text:
I could get the longer        
  throw of how to do a novel.

71.64.text:
But without cutting my     
     teeth on these stories

74.88.text:
that took me about       
       10 years to write,

76.78.text:
there's no way I could       
   write the long narratives

79.81.text: that I'm used to doing now.

81.68.text:
- The degree of these      
     stories vary greatly.

85.32.text:
What made you pick        
      to do a collection?

88.49.text:
- I set out to really      
     challenge myself.

92.96.text:
I could write from       
       the perspective

94.56.text:
of a male narrator       
       very, very easily.

97.30.text:
But I wanted to expand my scope 
and my trade craft really.

101.57.text:
A number of these short     
    stories take place

104.17.text:
in the mind of a          
      female protagonist.

107.41.text:
There are a couple        
      of occasions where,

109.71.text:
one story in particular     
    called Burn Unit,

113.18.text:
it's set in a Burn          
    Unit because I realized

115.52.text:
I'd never read a short story  
  that's set in a burn unit.

118.32.text:
I thought, well that       
     could be interesting.

122.12.text: I actually went to the burn unit

126.06.text:
I was able to shadow a      
    nurse around for a day.

128.66.text:
Then I went to talk to the   
   fire chief in Sioux Falls.

132.30.text:
The story just organically   
   came from that.

137.34.text:
Now, a lot of your stories   
   come from the perspective

140.34.text:
you wouldn't expect,       
     like a county coroner,

143.38.text:
or a stay at home        
       mom that you think

149.72.text:
But clearly what you create   
  for them is exciting.

154.99.text:
How did you think by        
    varying the perspectives

161.40.text:
- One of the things that    
    I really set out to do

163.63.text:
was to show that            
    although there might be

168.87.text:
and perhaps even uninteresting 
 from the outside,

171.10.text:
I don't believe that's      
    the case for any of us.

174.11.text:
- As a reader, I        
        sat there going,

181.58.text:
You get engrossed        
       in these lives,

184.82.text:
and it has that common theme  
  of leaving you wanting more.

188.35.text:
Was that intentional      
      on your part?

190.66.text:
- Yes, it was,            
      because I think that

194.96.text:
short stories are not      
     just short narratives.

200.03.text:
They have a particular way   
   of needing to be written.

204.17.text:
What I mean by that is,     
    a novel is usually about

207.91.text:
a community of people that   
   are involved in something.

211.31.text: We think of Dickens or Twain,

213.51.text:
or anyone that's been a      
   very successful novelist.

218.52.text:
We get a variety of souls and  
 lives that are intertwined.

222.36.text:
Short stories aren't      
      like that at all.

225.19.text: Short stories focus on one life

227.06.text: in a very brief flash of time.

230.96.text:
This is one reason why     
     so many of my stories

232.80.text:
sort of end with the         
   reader maybe wanting more.

237.57.text: I understand why you said that.

239.10.text:
But I think I've left enough  
  breadcrumbs in the story

241.51.text:
that the reader knows         
  what's going to happen next.

244.68.text:
But I trust them to figure   
   it out on their own.

247.11.text:
- Or imagine what's        
     going to happen next.

250.65.text:
- Each story, was there a    
   theme that it had to have

255.22.text:
in order to be a part      
     of this collection?

258.39.text:
- No, and actually         
     one of the challenges

260.33.text:
of putting all of these      
   stories in this collection

262.86.text:
was I realized, because     
    I was trying to write

265.13.text:
stories that were        
       of interest to me

267.17.text:
and what was               
     happening in the world

268.80.text: at that point in time, too.

270.17.text:
Before we started recording   
  we were talking about

272.67.text:
how some of the stories     
    deal with veterans.

277.61.text:
Because I was writing at      
  least three of these stories

280.21.text:
while we were in the       
     midst of the Iraq War,

282.38.text:
and some of the           
      students that I had

284.35.text:
at Augustana University,    
    then Augustana College,

288.32.text:
they were coming back        
   from Iraq and Afghanistan.

291.06.text:
I wanted to write        
       about their story

292.49.text:
because it didn't seem     
     that we as a nation

294.59.text:
were really listening       
    to what they had to say.

298.53.text:
- I think by doing that you   
  gave it a sense of rawness.

301.60.text:
Was that intentional      
      on your end?

303.50.text:
How, if at all, did       
      you pull that off

306.94.text:
to give a realistic        
     feel to your stories?

309.91.text:
- I believe that all      
      stories have to have

312.51.text:
what I refer to as        
      a moment of crisis.

315.52.text:
That is that there's       
     something that happens

317.45.text: in the story to the character

318.98.text: that you care about as a reader.

320.72.text: The writer's job is to focus on

323.92.text:
that moment of crisis      
     in a single life.

326.93.text:
So the rawness that       
      you're talking about

329.23.text:
is me just focusing the lens  
  of the reader's imagination

333.23.text:
on a particular point in    
    that character's life.

336.87.text:
Sometimes the stories      
     that inspired me,

339.87.text:
like the very first          
   story in this collection,

341.48.text:
57 Gatwick, is             
     inspired by Pan Am 103

346.78.text:
So the rawness that's in     
   my particular short story,

349.62.text: which is set here in Minnesota,

351.38.text:
is based on actual fact      
   that happened in Scotland,

354.99.text: and I just changed the setting.

358.56.text:
Well, if you want to pick    
   up Patrick Hick's book,

361.56.text:
a bunch of collections     
     of stories,

363.53.text:
as it says, The           
      Collector of Names,

368.10.text:
- Wherever good books      
     are sold, or online.

372.74.text:
So that's it for us in     
     The Literature Corner.

375.07.text:
Please tune in           
       next week for more

376.74.text:
people, places, and issues   
   facing our viewing area.

382.55.text:
and may your compass      
      always point you

384.68.text: in the direction of a good book.

is provided by the       
       ongoing support

401.13.text:
of the Leo P. Flynn Estate   
   of Milbank, South Dakota.

406.11.text:
the Southwest Minnesota      
   Private Industry Council,

408.84.text:
promoting Southwest       
      Minnesota as a place

412.75.text:
Come for the jobs,          
    stay for the lifestyle.
